text: I have remembered thy name, O LORD, in the night, and have kept thy law.
text_kjv: I have remembered thy name, O LORD, in the night, and have kept thy law.
text_niv: In the night I remember your name, O Lord,and I will keep your law.
text_esv: I remember your name in the night, O LORD, and keep your law.
text_nlt: I reflect at night on who you are, O LORD;therefore, I obey your instructions.
text_msg: I meditate on your name all night, God,treasuring your revelation, O God.
text_nasb: O LORD, I remember Your name in the night, And keep Your law.
context: Psalm 119 is an acrostic poem, with each section dedicated to a letter of the Hebrew alphabet. This indicates a deliberate and methodical approach to praising God and meditating on his law. The psalmist is likely facing adversity, perhaps exile or persecution, where fidelity to God's law becomes a source of strength and identity. The 'night' mentioned wasn't just a period of darkness, but often a time of vulnerability, fear, and introspection. Night was a time when dangers lurked, and the psalmist's vigilance in remembering God’s name and law suggests a conscious choice to resist fear and doubt. The frequent references to 'law' (Torah) do not signify a rigid legalism. Rather, they point to God’s revealed will, his instructions for living a life of blessing and righteousness. Remembering God’s 'name' was significant in Hebrew culture. The name represented the character, reputation, and very essence of the person. Recalling God's name was an invocation of his presence and power. The psalmist's commitment to 'keeping' God's law isn't simply about outward obedience; it reflects an internal alignment of the heart with God's desires. Finally, remembering God in the night, when distractions are minimized, highlights the psalmist’s deep commitment to consistent communion with God even amidst challenging circumstances. Therefore, this verse showcases devotion and unwavering trust.
meaning: Theologically, this verse embodies the concept of *anamnesis*, a remembering that isn't just recalling past events but actively making them present and effective. Remembering God’s name in the night is more than just recalling the letters YHWH; it’s calling to mind his attributes – his faithfulness, love, justice, and power – and experiencing those attributes as present realities. The 'law' here represents God’s covenant relationship with his people. Keeping the law isn’t merely about adhering to external rules but about participating in that covenant, embracing God's purposes, and reflecting his character in one’s life. The act of remembering and keeping during the 'night' emphasizes the importance of faith during times of darkness and uncertainty. It showcases a trust in God that transcends circumstances. It speaks to a reliance on God that isn’t dependent on feeling his presence or seeing immediate results. The verse highlights the relationship between knowing God (remembering his name) and obeying God (keeping his law). They aren’t separate activities, but integrated aspects of a life devoted to God. Knowing God leads to obedience, and obedience deepens one’s knowledge of God. This verse also implies the accessibility of God even in the darkest of times. God is not distant or unreachable; he is available to those who call upon him, especially when they are vulnerable and in need. The verse foreshadows the New Covenant, where the law is written on the heart (Jeremiah 31:33), and remembering God becomes an inward reality, influencing every aspect of life.
application: In today's world, Psalm 119:55 offers profound practical guidance. We all experience 'nights' – times of difficulty, uncertainty, and fear. Remembering God's name during these times means actively recalling his promises, his character, and his past faithfulness. It involves meditating on Scripture, praying specifically about our fears and needs, and intentionally focusing on God's presence. 'Keeping God's law' in this context isn't about meticulously following a list of rules but about aligning our choices and actions with his revealed will. This requires seeking wisdom through prayer, studying God's Word, and seeking godly counsel. Practically, this means examining our motivations and intentions, asking ourselves whether our actions reflect God's love, justice, and mercy. We can apply this verse by establishing daily routines that prioritize remembering God. This might involve setting aside time for prayer and Bible reading each morning and evening. It also means cultivating a mindset of awareness of God's presence throughout the day, constantly seeking to glorify him in our thoughts, words, and actions. It challenges us to make a conscious effort to resist negative thinking and to replace fear and anxiety with faith and trust in God. This verse encourages us to build a reservoir of faith during times of peace and prosperity, so that when the 'night' comes, we have a foundation of remembrance and obedience to draw upon. It also challenges us to be proactive in combating spiritual amnesia. Make time to intentionally recall and reflect on God's faithfulness, his promises, and his character. Share testimonies of God's provision with others, strengthening both your faith and theirs. Finally, consider the role of community. Sharing your struggles and victories with other believers can remind you of God’s goodness when you are struggling to see it yourself.
prayer: Lord, in the quiet darkness of my life, when fears and doubts creep in, help me to remember your name. Remind me of your unwavering love, your steadfast faithfulness, and your power to overcome any challenge. Write your law upon my heart, so that my thoughts, words, and actions may reflect your will. Give me the strength to choose obedience over fear, trust over doubt, and faith over despair. Lord, be present with me in the night, and guide me with your light. Strengthen my faith that I may always remember your promises. Help me to keep your law, not out of obligation, but out of love and gratitude for all that you have done for me. Thank you for always being present.

faqs.answer: Remembering God's name goes beyond just recalling the word 'LORD'. It means recalling and meditating on his character, attributes, and promises. It's about acknowledging his power, faithfulness, love, and justice, and actively considering these qualities in the context of one's life and circumstances, invoking His presence.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: What does it mean to 'remember God's name'?

faqs.answer: While salvation is by grace through faith (Ephesians 2:8-9), keeping God's law demonstrates the reality of our faith. It's not a means to earn salvation, but an expression of gratitude and a reflection of a heart transformed by God's grace. It shows our love for God.
faqs.question: Q2: How does 'keeping God's law' relate to grace in the New Testament?

faqs.answer: Praying, reading Scripture, listening to worship music, meditating on God's promises, and journaling are practical ways to remember God. Consciously choosing to focus on God’s character and promises instead of dwelling on fears can also help during difficult times.
faqs.question: Q3: What are some practical ways to remember God in the night?

faqs.answer: This verse offers hope to those struggling with doubt by encouraging them to intentionally focus on God's past faithfulness. Remembering times when God has come through in the past can strengthen their faith and help them trust God in the present struggle.
faqs.question: Q4: How does this verse apply to someone struggling with doubt?

faqs.answer: No. The 'night' is symbolic of difficult seasons of life – times of hardship, uncertainty, or spiritual darkness. The principle of remembering God and obeying his word applies to any challenging circumstance we face, regardless of the time.
